section.title: Introduction
section.para: The &suselinux; kernel provides everything to ensure stable operation on your computer. However, in some cases it is necessary to provide boot parameters to influence the boot process for &grub; or modify the behaviour of the kernel itself.
For example, you can control the Advanced Configuration and Power Interface (ACPI) settings, define the output console, enable debugging, and many more.
There are two methods to modify your kernel boot parameters:

formalpara.title: Temporarily
formalpara.para: After you have changed the kernel boot parameters, the change will be applied for the upcoming boot process. However, it does not survive subsequent boot processes.

formalpara.title: Permanently
formalpara.para: Your change is applied for each boot process.

section.para: As an example, we will disable the splash screen that you can see during the boot.

listitem.para: To only temporarily modify the kernel boot parameters, no prerequisites required.
To permanently modify the kernel boot parameters, you need write access to your root partition and the /etc directory.

section.title: Temporarily modifying kernel boot parameters
section.para: Test a kernel boot parameter, a temporary change is helpful. Such a change is only applied for the current boot process, not for any subsequent boot processes.

procedure.para: To temporarily disable the splash screen, proceed as follows:

step.para: Switch on your computer. The boot process will start.
In the &grub; boot screen, highlight the entry you want to modify using the arrow keys and .
Press the E key. You will be presented with an editor and the content of the selected boot entry. It will look similiar to the following:
step.screen: setparams '&productname; &productnumber;' # ... some lines pruned ... echo 'Loading kernel ...' linuxefi /boot/vmlinuz-5.3.18-lp152.87-default root=UUID=0dfcff43-7a61-4ecd-8df5-8dc56ee3d9f2 splash=silent resume=/dev/disk/by-uuid/0399f92e-5ed4-48c8-9db0-11e52c5cb0cd quiet mitigations=auto

step.para: Search for the string splash=silent and remove it.

To boot the entry, press F10 or
X .
To discard the changes and start anew, press the key.

section.para: During reboot, the splash screen is not shown.

section.title: Permanently modifying kernel boot parameters
section.para: If a change needs to be applied for every boot process, use this procedure.

procedure.para: To permanently disable the splash screen, proceed as follows:

step.para: In your running system, open a shell and view the current command line used by the Linux kernel:
As you can see, the string splash=line is printed. We will remove it for the next boot.
Look for the line GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT=. Remove the string splash=line from this line and save the file.

step.para: Reboot. You should see that the splash screen does not appear.
After your computer has successfully booted, log in and check your boot commandline:
